message: I've put code online, and submitted a few patches, but I don't know if anyone's actually using any open source code I've written.
Not that I'm a good open source maintainer (I'm terrible) but I think that's the way to do it, in general.
If you guys have advice - just let me know..

@bat I just started blogging, putting stuff out there, and participating on the developer lists of projects that I was interested (Django, etc.)  Then as I got more proficient, I started creating projects related to Django, and open sourcing them on GitHub.
How do you create projects people will want to use, and make sure people know about it?
i have been doing PHP for the past 6 yrs - now im wanting to help in Open Source development somewhere.
Just I doint know where to start or even the first step in helping in a php project.

I got started by being just a user (perl and mod_perl in my case) and started being involved in the mailing lists to get my own questions answered.  Then was answering questions for others, then helping write/edit the docs on the project.  And eventually code patches.  I think the easiest way to help and learn a particular project is to get involved in the documentation first, code second.
sounds like good advice. but for some reason - i have always joined lists but never participated in discussion. Ill have to get myself to engage the people.
I got really involved with open source a few years back when One Laptop Per Child was a thriving and innovating project, spawning communities all over the globe.
